With the arrests and dismissals of princes, Saudi Arabia seems to be heading into dangerous waters. For decades the princes were locked into a system where divided multiple security forces (Defense, National Guard, Police, Border Guard etc,) each with a prince at the head balanced each other other out. It was like a game of Jenga; while no one changed anything it looks like a strong structure, but if anyone tries to remove one piece there is a high risk of the whole edifice collapsing. Any freedom given to any group (e.g. women allowed to drive) or or taken away (e.g. restrictions on what the religious police can do) will destabilize Saudi society because the conservatives will not be happy. In Saudi Arabia, as in medieval Europe everyone "belongs" to a "sponsor", that is someone who gives them access to power and or protects them from power, if princes who are near the top of the pyramid are removed, their "people" have no one to look after them. In a hierarchical society like Saudi Arabia that is very upsetting because new hierarchies are not easily formed. 
In any autocracy the most dangerous time is when reform is attempted because those who benefit from the status quo will resent losing privileges while those who should benefit from change have their hopes raised, but are disappointed when the befits seem not to the coming fast enough. 
So the listing of Saudi Aramco could be seen not as an opportunity to  invest in a stable flow of oil, but a risky investment in an unstable country, in an unstable commodity that it past its peak.

While not directly related to Aramco's IPO there are signs of instability in Saudi Arabia that could possibly impact on the IPO. While events such as a minor prince being found misbehaving (see link below) are were not unknown in the past, as were stories of Saudi women ignoring the dress rules, these usually only came to light well after the event and were dismissed as rumors.  Until April 2016 the Mattawa (Religious Police) would have enforced the laws against alcohol and the laws on dress, but since then changed have been made, removing the right of the Mattawa to arrest people. As misbehaving is now being seen on social media I would expect more conservative Saudis would attribute at least part of the blame on the government (in effect the Royal Family) for being too modern. The Saudi state exists as a covenant between the Wahhabi religious establishment and the Saudi Royal Family, if the Royal Family is seen to be not backing the Wahhabi establishment enough, then the legitimacy of the Royal Family could be called into question.  If that happens who knows what will happen next.

There are several reasons why this is unlikely to happen. 
(a) They seem to be aiming for an IPO in 2018
(b) If the price of oil remains closer to $50 a barrel than $60 a barrel they might not be able to get the price they want
(c) Matters could come to light that make potential investors unsure of what they would be buying.
(d) Saudi Arabia may be more unstable that it appears to be. It is difficult to be sure how secure the position of the new Crown Prince is. It is known he likes to take decisive actions, but it is not clear if what he does is always wise. The Saudi society is very conservative and previous rulers (the Crown Price is the de facto ruler today) have been very careful not to make changes at a faster pace than society is ready to accept. The Saudi system (in common with many dictatorships) is based on having several different power bases below the King, none of which is quite powerful enough to seize control. These include religious and legal powers, as well as a number of well armed military and para-military forces that report to and are loyal to different ministers (who are also Princes and relatives of the King). Beside the forces of the Ministry of Defense, the Ministry of the National Guard has what is effect a second and counterbalancing army, the Ministry of the Interior has another group of armed land and sea forces. Any changes in Saudi Arabia have to take into account the rights and privileges of each of these groups that in many ways act as states within the state. Each group is headed by people who have traditional two way loyalties to the King and rights over aspects of the running of the state. Any changes to the status quo are bound to unsettle this balance of power. It is well known that reforming authoritarian regimes creates great risks to stability - expectations often jump ahead of delivery for those wanting changes, and those fearing the changes will try and stop them.
I am not trying to forecast what will happen to Saudi Arabia in the next few years , but an impetuous, inexperienced new de facto ruler could destabilize the country. This could be made worse by the end of oil money that has held the country together since the 1970s (before that the oil money was much lower). Although it seems that it is not always politic to acknowledge the fact, it is Saudi Arabia that has been where Al Queda and ISIS got a lot of its support, upset the fragile balance and it could turn into another failed Arab state.

Saudi Arabian Oil Co. hired Moelis & Co. to advise on its initial public offering, according to people familiar with the matter, as it pushes ahead with plans to pursue the world’s biggest share sale.
Aramco also recently asked banks including Goldman Sachs Group Inc. and HSBC Holdings Plc to pitch for advisory roles, people familiar with the matter said last month. The company plans to finish selecting banks later this year ahead of a listing in the second or third quarter of 2018, two of the people said.
JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Michael Klein, the former Citigroup Inc. investment banker who runs his own advisory firm, have already been selected to work on the IPO, people familiar with the matter said in April. Klein is providing strategic advice to the government, while JPMorgan is working on preparations for the IPO and may be among the banks that underwrite the listing, the people said.

1. Saudi Arabia is facing financial problems - these problems may reduce somewhat as oil price has crossed $50/barrel and has stayed there for some months now. This reduces the pressure on the kingdom to diversify. 
2. There is a prospect that oil prices could go up further in 2017 - as investment in upstream has reduced during 2015 (25%) & 2016 (24%) and may fall during 2017 as well - while oil demand has risen by  1.8 million bpd and 1.2 million bpd in 2015 & 2016 and is expected to go up another 1.2 million bpd in 2017 (IEA). This should reduce the pressure on monarchy to list Aramco. 
3. For a listing, Aramco will have to do roadshows in major financial centres in US and Europe where they will have to speak to investors and the media. The monarchy can face serious embarrassment at the hands of pro-democracy activists/journalists in such a setting - where they can be asked questions about freedom of religion in KSA, status of women, support to ISIS or the war in Yemen. Will the monarchy/country want to provide a forum where it can be questioned? Without some radical reforms which allows the kingdom to show a reformist face to the world, scrutiny by media can result in a major loss of face. 
4. Aramco will also need to make public a lot of financial and operational information - including information about the state of their oil fields - which they have so far hidden. These are difficult issues to resolve and will take time. It also needs to be decided on what information can/cannot be made public. 
5. Media reports indicate that the divestment in Aramco and the diversification of Saudi economy away from oil are initiatives of the Deputy Crown Prince, who is also in charge of the war in Yemen. This intervention has been going on since March 2015 (21 months now) - and seems likely to stretch. This reduces the credibility of the Deputy Crown Prince to carry out radical steps.

Besides the question of disclosures of reserves and accounts there is the issue of divisions within the royal family. The royal family has more members than most countries have Members of Parliament, but they are far from equal to each other and its never too clear how much power each member has. Oct 11 Saudi Aramco feels "comfortable" that by 2018 oil prices will have recovered and the market conditions will be right for what could be the world's largest public listing, its chief executive Amin Nasser said on Tuesday.

They want 1 entire Fiscal Year's worth of data under the International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS). Since Saudi Aramco is private, they do not have to adhere to those standards and likely currently do not. They basically need to convert all of their old Financial Statements into new Financial Statements based on IFRS and then implement it for 1 year to make sure they can do it. There are huge penalties for inaccurate financial statements, not only from fines but also from lack of trust from investors which would kill any chance of investing. This is not an easy task. Basically all of the processes at Saudi Aramco will need to change and they will likely need to purchase new software and hire more employees to make it happen. IPOs are not easy to pull off when your company is 20x the size of ExxonMobil.

Saudi Arabian Oil Co., known as Saudi Aramco, will announce “very soon” a list of investment banks and consultants advising it on the initial public offering, CEO  Amin Nasser said in Bahrain. without specifying a date. Its plan to sell a stake of about 5 percent could value the company in trillions of dollars.
The government hopes to raise about $100 billion from the planned IPO of its flagship asset.
“There are no obstacles for the IPO of Aramco,” Nasser said. “It’s going very smoothly, and we are on target. We achieved a lot of progress so far. People have to appreciate the size of Aramco and its complexity.”

Saudi Arabia would be unwilling to release financial data to the public on Saudi Aramco, which is a prerequisite for an IPO. Moreover, they would not want to dilute the complete control that they currently have over their main source of income, which incidentally would make it difficult to participate in the OPEC. On the other hand, they need the cash to finance their ambitious programme to become less dependant on oil. The fact that they maintain high production to get as much cash as they can under the low prices, while relinquishing their role as price regulator, could also suggest a different agenda. The IPO might be an option, but one that they will use only when other solutions have not worked. For the time, it should be interpreted as the seriousness of their intention for realising a different financial model, rather than a genuine IPO plan.

A Saudi I.P.O.? Buyer Beware
http://www.nytimes.com/2016/05/27/opinion/a-saudi-ipo-buyer-beware.html
By THE EDITORIAL BOARDMAY 27, 2016

They seem to be following the Ali Baba sleight of hand: Offering a minority participation priced as if it was a majority offering.  It's only challenging to accept the reality of this weird play because of how huge it is and how repressed their markets are. Otherwise, it's just another IPO (and a brilliant way to diffuse the impact of likely valuation collapse). Plus of course if Wall Street is in for a piece of the Vig it will happen asap.

Original articles centred on what Deputy Crown Prince Salman supposedly stated, i.e. that 5% of Saudi Aramco would be floated in 2017 or 2018. So start at a 50% chance in 2017. Confirmation was supposed to arrive within months but 6 months later there is still doubt. The Saudi Aramco chairman has not been definitively quoted as confirming this. Is it the parent company the Prince was even talking about or perhaps some of the downstream JVs? Wouldn't it be easier to create more JVs direct with International Oil Companies rather than satisfy the massive exchange rules and regulations in somewhere like NY or London. With 1.5 years left to run it must be less than 50% initial rate based on January's news releases but cannot be zero. 25%. Increases in oil price, waning of Prince Salman's credibility, internal strife based on succession to the throne likely to delay or eliminate this IPO and reduce my forecast.

Given the large size of Aramco, and it's massive number of stakeholders (literally an entire country) I think that it would be difficult to get the IPO done within 1.5 years. Also, well the government and especially the  Prince crown prince has been moving fairly rapidlyrecently, the kingdom runs on a consensus among the members of the royal family. It seems to me that getting enough key people to buy in could be very time-consuming. Remco could take several extra moments and still fall within the 2018 deadline.
They want to raise money as soon as possible to start their programs that will lessen their dependence on oil.

Saudi Arabia wants to diversify away from oil since it is no longer the "swing" producer of oil, developing completion of alternative and renewable energy sources, and the increasing recognition of and action on climate change issues around the world.
If the price of oil and gas continues to increase, then the Aramco IPO may be even more profitable and occur sooner!

Saudi Arabia is attempting to modernize their oil based economy.  A flotation of Saudi Aramco shares is part of the strategy.  Oil prices have sharply rebounded from the lows seen earlier this year, which leads to a higher valuation of Saudi Aramco.

Very high probability. They are looking to sell just 5% of the group initially. This is part of their wider move to modernize their capital markets, including Saudi sovereign bonds. As quoted in the Financial Post the prince said, "... the sale is planned for 2018, or even a year earlier." This suggests a fair degree of uncertainty about the Saudis ability to make this happen quickly. There are many things that could derail it or slow it down; Saudi public opinion may need to be massaged, the oil price might fall under $30 again, world financial markets might get hammered. It strikes me that each of these possibilities is at least a 10% chance. Lets add another 10% for a black swan, and another 5% because I'm feeling bearish today. That leaves 55% which still seems too high for something as complex and contingent as the biggest IPO ever. Lets call it even money.

Saudi Arabia's society is far more conservative than that of Japan, and Japan has been in recession for many years without the support or economic infrastructure to change quickly due to cultural and historical values and limited resources. Saudi Arabia is an an unprecedented level of economic crises. In April, Saudi Arabia raised $10 billion in bonds from JP Morgan, HSBC, and the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubitshi in the form of a 5-year loan. Moreover, this loan will increase S.A. debt level from 7% GDP in 2015 to 50% GDP by 2020. Such debt will be unsustainable without other sources of income, namely from a public offering of Saudi Aramco.
By allowing more non Saudis to buy shares in Aramco, they automatically allow other friendly and not so friendly nations to become partners.

Given the volatility in oil prices, Saudi Arabia seems to have grasped the nettle of the need for diversification and increased revenue collection. Selling shares in Saudi Aramco is part of that plan to deal with changing economic tides:

Selling bonds, issuing IOUs to certain creditors and selling off some of the assets will all be necessary for Saudi Arabia to maintain the expensive conflict with Iran.   Unless oil exceeds  expectations for a significant recover in price or a change in the hierarchy there will be continuing need for income to balance the budget and proceed with greater involvement in area politics.

Starting high because of the long timeline.

Saudi Aramco, the world’s largest oil company, is being readied for market. At the moment it is owned entirely by the Saudi Arabian government, but next year, if all goes to plan, anyone in the rest of the world will be able to buy a share in it

This has been mooted for some time, and the Saudi government are in severe need of funds due to the wildly fluctuating oil prices. Considering that oil is their biggest export to the world, they would be very keen to seek capital injections to their state-owned oil corporation. Add to that the fact that their currency reserves are severely depleted, and have already had to cut back on several subsidies. There is still plenty of time between now and Jan 2018 to successfully execute an IPO for Aramco.
Not to say that it can't be done in this timeframe, but I have some "how" and "what" questions.
Limited preparation to establish transparent corporate governance made before and after the IPO announcement.

Prince Muhammad says a listing would not only help the stockmarket, which opened to foreigners last year. It would also make Aramco more transparent and “counter corruption, if any”. A final decision has yet to be taken. Yet the prince has held two recent meetings with senior Saudi officials to discuss a possible Aramco listing and diplomats say investors are being sounded out. The talk is of at first floating only a small portion of the company in Riyadh, perhaps 5%. In time that could rise—though not by enough to jeopardise the kingdom’s control of decision-making.

Given the date is 2018. Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was quoted by Bloomberg early last month saying that Saudi Arabia was planning an IPO to sell shares amounting to around 5% of the company, as soon as next year.Saudi Arabia is planning a three-way stock market listing for state-owned oil and gas company Saudi Aramco in London, New York and Hong Kong, the British daily The Telegraph reported.
